pages.text: Antimony is a chemical element with the symbol Sb (from Latin: stibium) and atomic number 51. A lustrous gray metalloid, it is found in nature mainly as the sulfide mineral stibnite (Sb2S3). Antimony compounds have been known since ancient times and were powdered for use as medicine and cosmetics, often known by the Arabic name, kohl. Metallic antimony was also known, but it was erroneously identified as $(l:materials/Lead)lead$(/l) upon its discovery. The

earliest known description of the metal in the West was written in 1540 by Vannoccio Biringuccio.$(p)For some time, China has been the largest producer of antimony and its compounds, with most production coming from the Xikuangshan Mine in Hunan. The industrial methods for refining antimony are roasting and reduction with $(l:materials/Carbon)carbon$(/l) or direct reduction of stibnite with $(l:materials/Iron)iron$(/l).

The largest applications for metallic antimony are an alloy with $(l:materials/Lead)lead$(/l) and $(l:materials/Tin)tin$(/l) and the $(l:materials/Lead)lead$(/l) antimony plates in $(l:materials/Lead)lead$(/l)-acid batteries. Alloys of $(l:materials/Lead)lead$(/l) and $(l:materials/Tin)tin$(/l) with antimony have improved properties for solders, bullets, and plain bearings.
